alt_statements.statement: I think the best way to stop littering is to teach kids and adults why it’s wrong, like how it hurts animals and makes our neighborhoods look bad, and to show good examples at school and church. There should be plenty of trash and recycling cans around, with clear signs, and maybe small fines or having to do community clean-ups if someone keeps littering. I’d also like more community clean-up days where families work together, so everyone feels responsible for keeping our parks and streets clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time on trails watching birds, I see firsthand how litter harms wildlife and ruins the very places people come to enjoy. We should combine strict enforcement and meaningful fines with plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, plus public education that makes it clear we all share responsibility for keeping our parks and streets clean. I’d also support community clean-up programs and corporate responsibility laws so businesses have to help manage the waste their products create, instead of leaving it on taxpayers and the environment.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks so people don’t have an excuse to drop stuff on the ground. Grown-ups should also teach kids at school and church that God wants us to take care of the earth, so we feel bad about littering and try to keep our town clean.

As someone who works in a library and values clean, welcoming community spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical measures and education. Cities should provide plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, enforce reasonable fines for littering, and pair that with public campaigns—especially in schools—to teach people why caring for shared spaces matters. I’d also like to see more community clean-up events, where families and kids can take part, because when people feel ownership of their parks and sidewalks, they’re less likely to treat them like a trash can.

As someone who walks to work in a dense urban area and values both order and community responsibility, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart infrastructure and real consequences. Cities should place plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, funded in part by modest fees on high-waste products, and pair that with strictly enforced fines for littering. Public education campaigns—especially those that tie cleanliness to neighborhood pride and environmental protection—can help shift norms so people feel socially accountable, not just legally obligated.

As someone who spends long hours working to protect this country, it bothers me to see our own communities treated carelessly. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement—real fines that are actually applied—and straightforward public education, especially for kids, about personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces. I’d also support more trash and recycling bins in high-traffic areas, but ultimately people need to be held accountable for their actions.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime believing in personal responsibility and pride in one’s community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of clear rules and real consequences.
